description.text:
Braille files, feel free to remake it, this is just an .obj file to make easier the process of lettering in braille.
It is measured, it has braille proportions between dots, wide and height.
For better result, try to print it in vertical. There is a photo about that.
The first line are numbers
Second line is the alphabet in braille, and you have spanish single Ñ under it At the line below, there are other vowels, check the image. Also I like comments to know if it was useful for any user, so I can work on more accessibility digital items. Thank you!
I was spending a lot of time just making a phrase, so I hope this helps to get Braille closer to designers and printers. A bit faster than making from zero and measuring everything.

author: kskeuse

description.text: These combs fit the Bio-Rad vertical mini protein gels using the 0.75, 1.0, or 1.5 mm spacers. Bio-Rad doesn't sell 16-well combs, so they're useful when you have 15 samples and still want to load a molecular weight marker.

I printed these on a piece of blue painter's tape (to facilitate easy removal from the build platform) using a MakerBot Replicator 2. Using MakerWare software, I positioned the combs so that their wide flat side is down and printed using in PLA the default settings: medium quality, 10% infill, 0.2 mm layer height, 2 shells, and 230 degrees C.
UPDATE: The BioRad-advertised thicknesses of these combs is wrong.  FOr instance, the 0.75-mm comb is actually only 0.6 mm thick, and that makes a big difference in performance.  I've replaced the 0.75-mm file with a 0.6-mm file and the Sketchup file for modifications.

Had problems because the timing belt kinda hoped on the regular 30mm washer beside the bearing because of the 2Â° tilt of the Rostock-Idler so it didn't run smooth. This very simple printed washer absolutely made it. Could shurely be used for other printers aswell.

I'd recommend to put a regular small M8 washer between bearing and rounded washer, to keep the bearing turning while the carrying screw/rod is well fastened

description.text: Gonna need people's help here, I'm brand new to 3d modeling and have no printer to work with, so it's all trial and error. The theory goes that if you print either of these two items, place them in a bottle of water, top it off and close the cap, then squeeze it will act as a proper Cartesian Diver (or Devil) http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cartesian_diver I don't have the facilities yet to test this design, I'm hoping that the way i modeled it it should spin when you squeeze and release a couple times... if not... well back to the drawing board.. It was modeled in wings and if anyone wants a copy of the .wings file (or whatever wings3d can export to) just ask!

Print Bobbie 1 or 2, (remember to scale so it can fit inside a plastic (read: squeezable) water bottle,
Fill the bottle almost all the way, put Bobbie in, top it off, cap it and squeeze. the air bubble inside the Bobbie should be compressed and therefore sink to the bottom, then when you let go it will rise back to the top..
please report back on if this works or not, (and if it spins at all) Bobbie 1 should work, but if it's too buoyant then print Bobbie 2.. thanks!

title: Filament spool holder from a used whiteboard marker

description.text:
Note: chances are small that you have collected the same type of trash as I have got, so the presented thing might be only useful as an initial idea of your own spool holder design to enrich thingiverse with your own idea, in addition to hundreds of other spool holder designs available there.
At least once a month my chief is very unhappy. He arrives for about a week to our office to  interchange the ideas and resolve the issues, and he is really upset if a whiteboard marker doesn't give him enough color to express his visions on a whiteboard. Sometimes I throw out those bad markers, but not this time, when I've got a background problem to resolve: to build a filament spool holder that will not take a space which I don't have, and that can be temporary hanged somewhere near printer. So, the idea came to my mind, and I decided to give that marker a new shiny life in a world of 3D printing, as a spool holder core. I waited till weekend and started to implement a spool holder around the marker. I cut off a top and a bottom of the marker, found two relatively suitable bearings (having 8mm and 13mm diameters outside), and designed and printed simple adapters for the marker. Then I have found two metal angle clips which I had previously bought in local hardware store, cut off a part of one of them, threaded M3 holes for connecting clips and bearings, and assembled everything together with M3 screws. In order to make the spool holder to hang  perpendicular to the surface I have attached to it a piece of organic glass. To not scratch the surface of cupboard door where I want to hang the spool holder I have glued a piece of a soft puzzle mat with a double sided sticky tape to the organic glass. I have found a latch hook from an old camera case, and connected it to the spool holder with spare cable ties left after assembling RepRapPro Mendel kit. So, as a net result everyone are happy: my chief will be happier, because he will never accidentally grab this particular non-working marker for showing his idea on a whiteboard; a waste management company will be happier because less trash should be handled; and last but not least: I am now a happy owner of a reliable spool holder that is easy to install, and that takes virtually no space. So, modestly speaking, it's a brightest implementation of win-win strategy in its glory. :-)

If you have the same details as shown on the pictures:
  • Find out the same whiteboard marker as on the picture, it should be 14.5mm diameter outside.
  • Cut off a top and a bottom of it.
  • Print the adapters (I have used PLA with 0.4 mm layer height, and cooling fan turned on).
  • Attach all the adapters with the whiteboard marker tube as shown on the picture.
  • Assemble bearings with screws: M3 screw, M3 narrow washer, bearing, M3 narrow washer, M3 nut (screw should be long enough to be fixed on metal angle clips with nuts.
  • Put the assembled screws and bearings into the plastic adapters (screws inside).
  • Screw the assembled spool with the metal angle clips.
  • Screw a piece of organic glass or other flat material to the angle clip.
  • Glue a piece of soft mat with double sided sticky tape, and attach a latch hook with several cable ties.
    Done :-)

description.text:
The attached .pdf file is simply a list of links to upgrades of the MakerBot Replicator that are (mostly) found on Thingiverse.
While I love Thingiverse, it is sometimes impossible to find something you've seen before, regardless of search options.  This list just puts all of the Replicator upgrades in one place.

The list is in some rough categories, and items are simply chronological within those categories. No attempt is made to judge the usefulness of any entry, though the list makes it easier to compare items and judge for yourself. The d##### included with some entries is the derivative ancestor number(s). While I will probably update the list here occasionally, I intend to keep the list updated at least weekly at: http://www.eeweb.com/blog/gary_crowell/makerbot-replicator-upgrades NEW LIST UPDATED DEC 2, 2012
The new .pdf file now has the links embedded in the thing titles. NEW LIST UPDATED DEC 9, 2012
The new .pdf file now has the maker's links embedded in their names. I have also started including Rep2 and other 'bots things that look like they may apply to the Replicator. NEW LIST UPDATED DEC 23, 2012
The .doc file is now included with the .pdf. The list is also now implemented as a group of collections - one for each category, with the common prefix of "Replicator Upgrades - ". NEW LIST UPDATED JAN 3, 2013

A simple conveyor belt build platform for the MakerBot. It enables the MakerBot to do multiple prints without user intervention.
This is an initial prototype that does not support a heated build platform. I intend to add HBP support at a later time. I'm also still playing with conveyor belt materials. I've started with some Duralar I picked up for an art supply store. It has held up ok so far but more experimentation is required.
The intent here is to get the design out so people can play with it.

Full build instructions can be found at : http://www.evolvingmaker.com/makerbot-conveyor-build-platform:overview Note:
When using platform-v1.svg for laser-cutting the platform pieces, the color blue should be associated with a light etching power level.

comments.text: I'm very interested in building one of these, but need a bit of help with your bill of materials (BOM).  Could you big a bit more specific?
comments.author: dataman

comments.text: I'm currently using Duralar 14"x17"x.005". I got a package of 25 sheets from a Blick Art Materials here in Seattle. The belt is 430mm x 106mm (16.9" x 4.17") so length is really what dictates the size I get. I also picked .005" thickness in the hope that it would resist heat and warping better.
comments.author: dataman

comments.text:
One other note. I've had to scuff up the Duralar with 220 grit sand paper to improve cohesion. I did so in a criss-cross pattern much like what my original build platform has. This seems to improve things. The belt material
&
amp; design are likely to be the focus of considerable research
&
amp; testing for the next couple of weeks. As charlespax mentions, warping and durability is a significant concern.

comments.text: Very cool. Have you had any warping issues? What have you learned while building this?
comments.author: charlespax

comments.text: Thanks. I haven't had too many warping issues yet although it is still early in the belt material testing phase. The tractor gears hold the belt pretty taut, but I have noticed the belt edges  being bent up at times during the print. I plan to make changes in v2 that add small belt edge covers that will hopefully address this problem and hold the belt as flush as possible to the surface of the platform. Right now the tight fit of the belt and the fact the tractor gears are slightly lower than the top surface appear to provide decent performance.

120mm Fan Mount for a Mini Kossel 3D Printer. Works perfectly to cool prints and looks good doing it. Hides the mount points inside the fan. This bracket mounts to the top of the bed extrusion beams and is angled to blow directly across the bed surface. It attaches near the corner brace so it won't interfere with any bed mounts in the middle of the beams. The bracket is compatible with all standard 120mm standard width fans. Hardware required:
Qty 2: M3x8 hex cap bolt
Qty 2: M3x12 hex cap bolt
Qty 4: M3 hex nut

1) Printer settings were two perimeters with 25% infill.  
2) The fan sits on the bracket with one side directly in front of the vertical mounts. The fan attaches to the mounts with two M3x12mm bolts and hex nuts. Washer on the outside make it look nicer but are not necessary.  
3) The bracket attaches to the beams around the bed with two M3x8mm hex cap bolts in the counter sunk holes going in to two hex nuts in the extrusion channels. Position the mounting point near the corner brace so the fan is pointed at the center of the bed and tighten the bolts.

comments.text: i was curious to know how this fan works for prints taller than the fan?
comments.author: ekaggrat

comments.text: It works ok. The problem once the print gets taller than the 120mm of the fan is that it tends to mostly cool things on the side of the fan and stops working so well on the opposite side. For tall prints you either want two fans or ideally a fan added to the effector platform blowing directly down on the print.

description.text:
Features of this Mars habitat:
  • Pyramid shape that is rigid against strong winds with 4 stabilizing beams that are deep into the planet's surface for added strength.
  • Double structure design for safety. The outer pyramid interior space would have extra food producing plants, machinery, and other large things that are not absolutely important. The interior pyramid space is where crew would live most of the time and where the most important things like electronics would be. There would also be an underground structure below the interior pyramid for added space and safety that would be primarily storage and systems that maintain a breathable atmosphere.
  • 4 airlock doors with 4 separate sections of the outer interior space. This would allow for sections to be maintained while still having enough space for at least the plants that need atmosphere to survive. Also good in case of a breach, so that only one section would be down while being repaired.
  • Dual solar collection system, both Solar Power Tower with heliostats and photovoltaic type devices would be used.

The capsules are created for the different programs that make up the settlement and are designed to allow for more diverse activities than similar designs in the aerospace industry today.  By taking the solid tubes and adding inflatables like I discussed earlier, I was able to almost triple the square footage from 380 sq. ft. to 1090 sq. ft. when the capsule lands.  The inflatable in turn determines the smallest that the ring of capsules can be and helps to organize the settlement.  The inflatable combined with the augmentation screens will also allow for teleconferencing with Earth similar to when Curiosity landed and sent back its first pictures to Times Square (albeit with a delay of between 15 and 40 min).

description.text: It's a Space Invader. 'Nuf said.

I designed it in inkscape (invader.svg) using 2.5x2.5mm squares as "pixels". Later I outlined it and saved it in dxf format (invaderout.dxf). I then passed it through a simple scad linear_extrude to make it 2.5mm tall. Slice and print.
The diagonals had to have extra "offset pixels" to make them hold together. The eyes are also 1.5 pixels wide to make them a bit larger to (e.g.) thread thick cotton through and put on a keyring.

With a vertically expandable plinth or ground/floor level, individual rooms, research facilities, and work-spaces stretch away from the rugged and rocky, red terrain of Mars.  
The base would house it's own rammed-Mars facility, 3-d rapid prototyping lab, and concrete plant.  All the construction would take advantage of Mars' already rugged terrain as aggregate for building material.  With a lack of gravity, fabric, tensile structures can be used as form-work for the concrete spaces.  The thick "concrete" walls would shield from Mars' extremely cold exterior temperatures.  While all the spaces are connected by the common ground-level, inhabitants residing in each volume would circulate vertically  taking advantage of the weaker gravitational pull.  The main premise of this is to tread lightly...to use what mars already has in abundance.

I tried to imagine not only what a structure on mars might feel/look like but I was thinking how to build it when you are up there.  I designed the geometry by hand, then rhino3d, then exported to makerware and printed.  you can print it too!  
In the folder you can find a clean rhino3d file and an stl file...

Table designed to be used in groups of 3 to from a larger hex table.

Instructions with Photos
https://sites.google.com/a/g.essextech.org/makerspace/projects/hextable More Photos Here
https://picasaweb.google.com/101126821429911112952/HexTablePhotos
Â This a a table that is designed to so that 3 or 6 of them will form a hex pattern for a classroom. The design above is for 3 tables. Each table is designed to be cut from 3/4" material on a CNC machine. For the prototypes I have been using 1/8" Hardboard (Masonite Type) Panels and printing on the laser cutter at 1:6 scale. I will need to make some changes when going to the CNC machine to allow for the tool size.
A designed the table in GoogleSketchup using the PRO version. I then took each component and laid it on a flat surface in Sketchup. I then zoomed in on only the parts I needed and exported to dwg. I need to turn the view->Parallel Projection in order to avoid scaling errors. See the photo below. The Table top and legs don't mate together. I realized that if I looked at the exported dwg you could see the error in there also.
After correcting the export from Sketchup I was able to get a design that worked. I imported the dwg into Corel Draw on the computer attached to the laser engraver/cutter. When importing into Corel Draw I scaled the dwg by 1:6. The photos below are from the second version of the design. I also engraved the top with name of the table. .
The Sketchup drawing below is of the most recent version. I have not yet had a chance to print and test this design. It incorporates some changes to allow the legs to slide together. It also includes a shelf on the bottom that locks the legs together.


Laser Cutter Settings for 1/8" Masonite.
Black was used to engrave the letters on the top of the table. Red was used to cut the design. Blue was NOT used or tested.
I also found it easier to turn OFF the z-axis. I used the jog controls to move the laser over the top of the surface and then set the depth using theÂ gauge and the z-axis jog buttons on the Laser.Â

A faithful rendition of Chu's Arduino bumper version 6 redrawn in DesignSpark Mechanical. I needed an Arduino case with some extra features, so my first step was to take the dimensions from the original bumper and redo it in DesignSpark Mechanical, as I don't have Autodesk Inventor. Other than the different CAD file format, it should be the same as the original.  
Original STL mesh is included but hidden in the rsdoc file so you can verify the accuracy. If you use it, I recommend pulling the exterior walls out a bit as the original is only 0.029", or ~.74mm, which is just under two extrusion widths at 0.40mm width extrusion.

title: Wallace style x-ends x-carriage for Prusa Mendel  i2

description.text:
Here are some custom Reprap Wallace style x-ends and x-carriage for the Prusa Mendel i2. Designed for M8 rods and LM8UU Bearings. I love the simplicity of the Wallace and being able to mount an extruder that wouldn't get in the way of the x-belt. You can use a 624 Bearing for the idler pulley. On the x-carriage I moved the bottom carriage rail to the other side to allow for some extra space. The end stop switch mount has been integrated into the motor x end.
I also included my FreeCAD design file.
Hope you like it.

title: Trippers for the light duty Intermatic Timer TN111

description.text: Where do socks go? the same place these little guys go! Every year I dig these timers out for my Xmas lights and every year I'm missing these little trip pieces. These are for light duty Intermatic timers, 'theroar' has thing 26680 which works for the heavy duty version of the timer.

All parts were printed on a TOM with a MK6+. My settings were: Object infill% 100, Layer height(mm) .27, Number of shells 0, feedrate (mm/s) 30.
These fit snuggly into place, push them in as far as they will go.
The file includes a set of ON and OFF pegs for a light duty Intermatic Timer model TN111. Now you can tell your significant other that you saved $4 with your $1000+ 3d printer!

title: Dryer lint vacuum attachment for Dyson DC27 (I think)

description.text: Our new dryer has an annoying thin screen that allows too much lint to bypass it, and we have to constantly try to vacuum it out.  But the attachments I have for the Dyson don't get into the nooks and crannies, so I came up with an adapter that would allow me to use an ordinary plastic hose.

Go to your local hardware store and pick up 1' of plastic hose with an OD of 5/8" and ID of 1/2".  
Print both pieces.  Both can be printed without support material.  I purposely lofted the interior of the top of the adapter for this reason.  The large opening is also lofted to match the taper of the end of the Dyson vacuum cleaner.  The "fingers" are also tapered, along with the inside of the nut to try to make them compress the hose, which seems to work.  
Stick one end of the hose through the "nut", and then continue to pass this end into the "adapter" until the end of the hose is flush with the interior wall.  The intent was to have a lip on the inside, but when I added the loft I destroyed this feature and didn't realize it.  
In a future iteration, I would probably make the adapter entry a little larger on the next pass, as well as make the "fingers" a little thicker.

comments.text: I used a 3 foot hose (.45/ft from Lowe's) attached to a Rigid shop vac with car cleaning kit.  Some jerk ace broke 2 of my car windows and this let me get into tight areas my crevice tool couldn't. Thank you!

Simple Pods that fit together. Keeping it simple.
Sketchup

This makes slicing STL files two to five times faster when using ReplicatorG and Skeinforge. This is done via an alternative Python interpreter (PyPy) which is much faster than the default one. This is a pre-compiled version for Mac OS X only. You can download PyPy for other operating systems here: http://www.pypy.org/

Mac OS X Instructions: 1) Download disk image and double click to open it. 2) Drag the 'pypy-osx' folder to your Applications folder. 3) Open the ReplicatorG Preferences and click the 'Advanced' tab. Click 'Select Python Interpreter'. Browse to the pypy binary in the folder copied in step 2: Applications -> pypy-osx -> bin -> pypy. 4) Close preferences and slice faster! This should work on any Intel-based Mac. Xcode is not required! Example slicing differences:
mini Barrel-O-Monkeys toy (thing:27553) went from 44 minutes to 4 minutes.
"Snake went from 2:02 to 46 seconds."
"Bracelet from 24 minutes to 7 minutes!!"

description.text: This is a phone cell stand which can be fixed on a bike or put on a car dashboard. It has been built by laser cutting a 8mm thick Plexiglas sheet. the cradle is tailored for a Samsung GT-S5360 (length: 104mm, width: 58mm, thickness: 11.5mm). There's room for improvement on making the cradle width and thickness ajustable to fit any mobile handset size, with a laser cutting implementation.

In anticipation of the festive season, and the fact that we have a pounce on anything that remotely looks pouncable, cat, I needed to make some lockable bauble clips.
So here is a design for one. These can be made out of PLA if you want and thus when the tree gets thrown out you can throw the clips out as well. But they are also reuseable if you plan on making them out of ABS

Print raftless. As it doesn't really matter that they warp or are not level and will save you hours separating the clip from the raft.
Also only do the lower branches that are in a cats reach.
Enjoy!

Hello! I wanted a better sheath for one of my hunting knives (the one it came with is leather, which is not practical in wet conditions.)
The Sheath is designed for a left sided belt carry, but could be mirrored to accommodate right-handed users. I built in a drain hole so that moisture can't accumulate inside.
The sheath is designed for a Cold Steel Outdoorsman, which has a 6 inch blade, but could be modified to fit any knife by changing the profile of the second inner layer and the overall length of the model.
As I've previously mentioned, I don't have a printer, so please share any pics of prints!

description.text:
• 05/11/2014 Finally added a BOM.cvs
     
  • 09/10/2014 Added a new version. V1.5 With some important modification.
    I positioned the Z-axis motor outside the structure, the only 3d piece
    changed is the 17_Z_Screw_Driver.stl, it must be replaced by the 40_Z_Screw_DriverV1.5.stl
    You can see a new project on tinkercad her:
    https://www.tinkercad.com/things/bhpW4FNh38z-miracube-with-1-hotend-v15
     
  • 09/10/2014 Added entire set of x carriage for 1 hot end only
    • 37_x-carriage_1_hot_end.stl
    • 38_X_car_Belt_1_hotend.stl
    • 39_X_car_fan_1_hotend.stl
      In this case you can print only 1 exstrusion set.
       
  • 05/09/2014 Added a 40mm fan duct for PLA printing
    • 36_x_carriage_fan_duct.stl
       
      A videos of the Miracube in action can be viewed here:
      https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X2z2qGbcNx4&feature=youtu.be
      https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f-N60tMJTgc&feature=youtu.be
    •  
    A Corexy 3D printer.
    This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online
    https://www.tinkercad.com/things/f7uonb7lb4N-miracube-v10
    From the above tinkercad link you can build simply the MiraCube. In the 3d tinkercad project you can compute all the measure of aluminium extrusion profile.
    I used two type of brico aluminium extrusion profile
  • 10mmx10mm
  • 20mmx10mm
    Yuo can rescale the entire printer on axis Y and Z. For the resacaling on the axe X You must reengineer the heatbed support mount.
    In the tinkercad link below you can see a rescaled MiraCube with a volume of 20x40x30
    https://www.tinkercad.com/things/fpE4DgV8KrO-miracube-20x40x30
    For the X Y and Z sliders I used 8mm smooth rods (you can get the lenght from thinkercad project) and a LM8UU linear bearing.
    For the kinematic motion I used 4mm inner hole ball bearing and a GT2 belt.
     
    If you like the printer can write a comment or leave a feedback.
    Thank you.
     
    Una satmpante con cinematica Core XY
     
    Questa stampante è stata creata a partire dal progetto pubblico che puoi trovare su Tinkercad al link:
    https://www.tinkercad.com/things/f7uonb7lb4N-miracube-v10
    A partire dal progetto Tinkercad puoi costruire la Miracube con estrama facilità. Nel progetto puoi calcolare e ricavare ogni singola misura di ciascun pezzo in alluminio.
    Per la stampante in foto ho utilizzato due tipi di estrusi in alluminio facilmenti reperibili in un qualsiasi negozio brico (Leroy & Marlin, Brico, Obi, etc.):
  • barre da 10mm x 10mm
  • barre da 20mm x 10mm
    Inoltre, sempre dal progetto Tinkercad puoi scalare l'intera struttura della stampante sia sull'asse Y che su quello Z. Per l'asse X andrebbe reingegnerizzato il supporto per il piatto riscaldato.
    Nel link di seguito puoi trovare già un progetto scalato con dimensioni di stampa 20x40x30
    https://www.tinkercad.com/things/fpE4DgV8KrO-miracube-20x40x30
    Per gli slider X, Y e Z ho utilizzato delle barre rettificate da 8mm e dei cuscinetti lineari del tipo LM8UU. Anche in questo caso puoi ricavare la lunghezza delle barre dal progetto Tinkercad.
    Come cuscinetti a sfera per la Cinematica XY ho utilizzato dei cuscinetti con foro interno da 4mm ed una cinghia dentata GT2.
     
    Se ti piace la stampante scrivi un commento o lascia un feedback.
    Grazie

comments.text: V1.0 would suggest that you would do a follow-up at some point :) Would you still be using the aluminum rectangular tubes or you would go for t/v-slot? If so, for what reason?
comments.author: mbthor

comments.text:
Hi, mbthor, in this prototype I used the aluminum rectangular tubes for various reasons.
First, are readily available at any Brico centre, furthermore, I can join them with printed parts simply with a wood screws, available at any Brico centre.
This is my first experiment, the V1.5 is an evolution with one hotend, but with a motor inside the cube and other little features.
The V2.0 is another and definitive evolution of this project.
I made about 20 V2.0 for friends and some customer
All the versions of my printers have each 2-3000 hours of work and tons of filament used both PLA or ABS
The only modification that I suggest is the use of a trapezoidal screw for Z motion and at the same time the placement this screw between the two Z steel bars.
In general all the version of those models of CoreXY printer are reliable and accurate as well as easy to assemble.
comments.author: mbthor

comments.text: Any idea where I can buy the aluminum extrusions?
comments.author: whitewolf103187

comments.text:
Hi whitewolf103187,
I bought them in a Brico center or hardware store near my home. You can find them also in any online hardware shop. The size are 10mmx10mm and 10mmx20mm and are empty with a 1mm thickness.
I hope I have helped you

Print plug.

description.text:
Basics (well not so basic)
• Module to be transported via spacex on falcon rocket.
• Module concept developed off spacex dragon 2 capsule.
• Module enters mars via nasa inflatable heat shield and dragon 2 re-entry rockets. Module design ideas • Due to the limited gravity on mars, inflation of the module will be easier than on earth.
• The light weight construction of the frames due to 3d printing technologies will also aide in the erection of the unit.
• Utilising lightweight but ultra-strong fabric such as that used on the space station as the outer and inner skins of the module will save on weight.
• Once the module is erect, liquid insulation/foam will be sprayed in the middle layer aiding in thermal protection and added protection from the harsh environment of mars.
• To achieve the insertion of the foam into the middle layer, the internal frame will have holes positioned along its length.
• The inner fabric will have a network of pipes to aide in the even distribution of the foam.
• An internal heating/cooling system will be situated in the floor of the module with the power units also being located in the floor.
• Electricity to the module will be provided via internal batteries and pv cells. Alternatively a central electricity system will be provided i.e. an array of solar panels connected to an electrical substation module once a more established mars base has been erected.
• Electricity to be distributed under the bridge as per the oxygen path ways. Other modules will house such items as water treatment plants, bathrooms, sleeping quarters, laboratories, greenhouses and general storage modules.
• Grappling lugs to be located under bridge to allow for connection of interconnecting modules Further investigations: • Rib design to allow increase capacity
• Experiment with hatch size to allow for ease of flow between modules.
• Investigate balancing of module size vs resources needed i.e. oxygen and electricity (heating)
• Utilising the trunks of the transport rockets for additional not critical items which will be provided on mars via smaller re-entry rockets
• Housing small power plants for co2 processing equipment.

I've tryed to respond to 2 major questions about Mars colonisation. The weight and size of the construction for the space travel and the radiation factor. The basic idea was to bring empty bricks and fill them with martian sand creating a natural radiation shield and gives in the same time weight and strength to the whole structure.
The ingot shape is usefull to imbed layers and so take as less space as possible for the transportation. You could also consider the high flexibility and modularity of such structure that may help the colony to adapt to the planet.

I took Vezkah's Printrbot Simple Metal Spool Holder 2.0 and resized the hole so it fit on the original Simple. Works great on my Printrbot Simple 2014!
The full size is too big to print on the Simple 2014 itself, but I've included a scaled down version that will fit the 2014 - however I'm not sure if all spools will clear the printer on this smaller version - let me know if it works for you! Be careful with very high prints, I managed to dislodge the string on the Y-axis of my simple because it was rubbing against the spool holder.

Print at 25% > infill and slide it on one of the z-axis posts!
To get the "small" version to print on the Printrbot Simple 2014/ Makers edition, you will need to rotate it 45 degrees on the Z axis (IE: put 45 in the Z box on the rotation line in Object Placement)

comments.text: Just what I was looking for!  I have a Printrbot Simple metal but need spool holders for two Printrbot Simple Makers Kits a 2013 and 2014.  Thanks for sharing.  Now I'm off to printing.

Inspired by phookys printable foosball player ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1090 ). I wanted to make a player that was closer to the ones used on Tornado tables. I have included the blender file for anyone who would like modify it. UPDATE:
I have shortened the toe / leg a bit to be a better fit. I have also added a hole for a counter sunk 8-32 x 1" screw to attach the player to the rail. UPDATE:
Having mounted this to the table I have now added counter balance and resized.
I have included stl's with the player positioned both toe down and head down. I suspect that head down will be the way to go.

description.text:
We created this cute toy to explain how an object can be 3D printed with moving parts without having to use support or raft. We hope that it will be the first of a collection. Maybe the next vehicules will have integrated hinges for the doors and a working steering wheel! We saved it in 3 different sizes. Original, wich is 80mm.
150% and 320% (full size for a Replicator 2)

description.text: V. 1.3 Can now be found in Downloads. Improvments include: - Extra support ring, keeping the pieces in place more effectively - larger size, more relvent to average ring size for adults V. 1.2 has now replaced V. 1.1 in Downloads. Improvment include: - Pieces now fit together more effectivly - Spinning action improved The object is a simple spin ring with interchangeable parts. The purpose, being that this would have a wide appeal to many people, with a variety of needs for it. The solution the spin ring provides applies to many individuals. It helps those with ADHD and similar conditions stay focused, it helps stressed individuals keep occupied, and helps calm Obsessive compulsive disorders and similar compulsive actions. The way the spin ring provides these solutions, is through a simple movement on the device as the user wears it. The user can spin the piece, and it will help them remove their attention from things that stress and or distract them, or from compulsive tendencies, and re apply their attention effectively first to the ring, and then onto to more important tasks in their daily life.

comments.text:
Hey there, thanks for the comment!
The most up to date version of the ring, (v.1.3) Comes in at 22 MM
This is closer to the size of a size 12 or 13 (US) ring.
So for your ring size, i would look at making it slightly smaller when printing.
%90 - %95 of the original size may do the trick.

This is an idler with teeth to increase the ability to hold the tracks in place. If attached to a power source somehow they'd be able to drive the treads but that was not my intention (I'll be making one of those soon based on this design). This is for: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:35668 The length between points was found to be different than expected through trial and error. Sorry - Had to update... it helps to double-check that the hub doesn't interfere with the gear part of it. Now fixed. And one more fix - I should really test before releasing my items. hehehe. Adjusted outside diameter of teeth down quite a ways. Adjusted width of teeth up a bit and made angle a little better for printing.

I printed at 0.4mm layer height and 25% infill with solid every 8 layers, this may have been overkill.
Fasten wheel in place with #10 or 5mm screws (might need a little filing with 5mm) remembering washers both sides of the hub.

A set of snap-on covers for the MakerBot's stepper motor printed circuit boards and its motherboard.
I have included the SolidWorks part files and the STL files.

Print with a 3D printer. For the stepper covers, ensure the letter on the cover corresponds with the letter of the stepper board.
The two parts of the motherboard cover need to be glued together. Use hot glue along the seams where the two parts butt.
Once parts are complete, press fit onto boards.

description.text: A small ornamental nativity set.  We used them as cracker fillings last year.  Really minimal design.

The OpenSCAD file contains one of each figure, Mary, Joseph, a shepherd, a king, an angel and the crib.  To print a bigger set you can print separate figures multiple times.  The source file is reasonably well commented but you'd best be familiar with OpenSCAD.

I printed in clear PLA then painted the models with Tamiya model acrylic paint, the effect for the angel's wings when left in clear PLA is quite nice.

title: Reusable DIY Board Game Miniatures Stand

description.text:
Make your own miniatures using only this handy stand, a printer and a pair of scissors.   
Steps:

• Search around or draw a character/object with a front and back face.
  • Print your image.
  • Start printing your stand.
  • While stand is printing, cut out your miniature. Remember to leave about 1 cm of extra space at the bottom of each half for stand tabs.
  • Fold or Glue the two halfs of the miniature together. Do not glue stand tab area.
  • Once your stand is printed, clean up the tab slot, and measure.
  • Cut your tabs width down to fit slot in stand.
  • Slot miniature into stand.
  • Add some sticky tack or childrens modelling clay to give weight to the base and hold the tabs firm.
    • Original art work for my example miniature found through google images:
    http://ichi-graphics.blogspot.co.uk/2010/08/slipshod-character-concept.html

title: Laser cut tree in a round frame

description.text: I made this for a friend's wedding. Original is 20" in diameter, you probably don't want to scale it down too much or the thinner branches will get burned by the laser

comments.text: Cutting this now full size!  As LaserBot3000 has said, many cuts are double cuts, and some have lines that are offset a bit, but more or less parallel to others.  I had to do some editing to clean it up, then in my laser software have it remove duplicate lines (about 7300 of them).  It cut the lasering down by more than half.
comments.author: cncpadawan

comments.text:
Love it! I made a version of your gorgeous tree adapted for 3D printing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1181752
I hope you approve. :)
comments.author: FrankLumien

comments.text: I made this scaled down to just under 12" diameter (290 mm to be exact), in spite of the warning not to scale this down too much. It came out beautifully! Of note: All of the inner small cuts are double cuts, meaning the laser will go over them twice. But the two outer rings are not double cuts. Be aware of this when importing the design into your laser cutting software. I believe if the laser had only gone over the inner parts once then the tiny branches wouldn't be nearly so fragile.
comments.author: LaserBot3000

description.text: makes cool laser cut labels for platic storage containers.

why this is cool:
  • you can use this to make your own DXFs. The SVG->DXF pipeline seems to work well on the Bristol Hackspace laser cutter.
  • you could link this program to a spreadsheet and automatically cut your own labels as you add new items.
    • you'll need:
  • a good laser cutable font. I recommend this one 'Stencil Gothic JL'
  • an old version of pysvg: http://code.google.com/p/pysvg/downloads/detail?name=pysvg-0.2.1.zip&can=2&q=
  • some python modules that can query ttf fonts: http://pypi.python.org/pypi/TTFQuery and http://sourceforge.net/projects/fonttools/?source=dlp
  • an up to date version of pstoedit http://www.pstoedit.net/
  • inkscape
    • then run from the command line
./makeLabel.py --text "tape"

description.header: for a sheet, use a newline separated file of text
description.text: ./makeLabel.py --file labelfile
./makeLabel.py --help latest version always on github: https://github.com/mattvenn/cad/blob/master/hackspace%20labels/makeLabel.py
Base

This is a hydraulic powered crane/digger/bucket thing. Not quite sure what to call it. It is powered with Syringes that slide into the holes and attach to to the syringe mounts. I use it as a project in middle school and was built using Solidworks. Really fun project and really fun to use. Aside from the parts you will be printing, you will need the following items... 10cc Syringes: 10x
Approximately 6-10 feet of Airline tubing
Assorted dowel rods to connect pieces together

comments.text: This should be relatively straight forward to work out without instructions just following the rendering of the 3D built version. However I got totally stalled by the orientation of all the parts - nothing is square on an axis and at least using Slic3r it's virtually impossible to try and get everything laying flat on the bed to print this which is a real shame since it looks awesome and yesterday my daughter asked me to explain hydraulics!

One of several exits to Mars but the main exit from the Primary Structure Chem/Bio

Additional R&D Manufacture of Base Products

Vehicle pickup

comments.author: gammaworld1

description.text:
I'm obviously stuck on making vessels lately and throwing lights in them. It's the ceramicist in me resurfacing and joining hands with my, uh, inner interior designer?
I've also been testing Taulman 618 nylon filament. Google it and buy some if you haven't already. It's really fun stuff with properties that will greatly expand your printing capabilities.
Anyway, beyond it's mechanical properties, I've noticed that the nylon does really cool things with light. Both of the pieces pictured were printed one perimeter thick and they just glow when lit, pics don't do justice. The big one (V4) had some kind of issue that caused a big dent when it was about 80% done printing. Should be a smoother profile than that.
Print with zero infill and as few perimeters as you can, no top solid fill.  One perimeter will leave an occasional gap on overhangs so two shells might be the way to go if you want a tighter print.

I'm working for UMBC lab peoples; they needed a means of attaching specialized grips to a PlayStation controller they rigged for their wheelchair.
I designed this replacement joystick with attachments.

The center post is lower than it should be in order to be printed properly; it needs to be sanded/cut by about 3mm (or just look at the actual joystick and reduce the printed one by the same amount).
If the model fits too snugly in the controller, try smoothing the rounded spherical part, and reducing the center pillar on the bottom.

author: hamza

description.text:
I'm working for UMBC lab peoples; they needed a means of attaching specialized grips to a PlayStation controller they rigged for their wheelchair.
I designed this replacement joystick with attachments.

Cylinder Attachment 1 is skinnier and has a flat top. Orient it to print with the flat top on the platform. Cylinder Attachment 2 is more exact to the dimensions that they wanted, but has a rounded top and is more difficult to print (refer to 2.2 and 2.3) Cylinder Attachment 2.2 and 2.3 are version 2 in two separate pieces, with flat surfaces for printing. Print both and glue them together. DO NOT PRINT THREADED SIDE DOWN; YOU RISK THE THREADS NOT TURNING OUT WELL ENOUGH TO WORK
